data.title: Computational lexical analysis of Flamenco genres
data.text:
Pablo Rosillo-Rodes Maxi San Miguel David SÃ¡nchez

Abstract

Flamenco, recognized by UNESCO as part of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity, is a profound expression of cultural identity rooted in Andalusia, Spain. However, there is a lack of quantitative studies that help identify characteristic patterns in this long-lived music tradition. In this work, we present a computational analysis of Flamenco lyrics, employing natural language processing and machine learning to categorize over 2000 lyrics into their respective Flamenco genres, termed as palos. Using a Multinomial Naive Bayes classifier, we find that lexical variation across styles enables to accurately identify distinct palos. More importantly, from an automatic method of word usage, we obtain the semantic fields that characterize each style. Further, applying a metric that quantifies the inter-genre distance we perform a network analysis that sheds light on the relationship between Flamenco styles. Remarkably, our results suggest historical connections and palo evolutions. Overall, our work illuminates the intricate relationships and cultural significance embedded within Flamenco lyrics, complementing previous qualitative discussions with quantitative analyses and sparking new discussions on the origin and development of traditional music genres.

I Introduction

In the past decade, there has been a significant drive to utilize computational techniques to investigate intangible cultural heritage. These efforts encompass a broad range of activities, from the development of cultural platforms and databases [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6] to the application of social signal processing to oral history collections [7]. Additionally, there have been explorations into artistic folklore studies, such as various approaches for analyzing dance movements [8, 9, 10], analysis of musical metrics of contemporary western popular music through the decades [11, 12], and advancements in music innovation studies [13]. Our research aims to contribute to the understanding of the lyrics of Flamenco, a musical tradition deeply rooted in culture but scarcely studied with quantitative methods.

Flamenco, a rich oral musical tradition originating in Andalusia, a region in southern Spain, reflects a diverse tapestry of cultural influences. Throughout the centuries, this region, along with its musical expression, has been significantly shaped by various cultural settlements. Notably, the influences of Jews, Muslims, and folkloric music from different Spanish regions are discernible contributors, yet undeniably, the cultural imprint of Andalusian gipsies is deeply embedded in the essence of Flamenco ([14], p. 469-473). Recognizing its distinct features and profound significance for the cultural identity of Andalusia, Flamenco was honored with inclusion in the UNESCO List of Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity in 2010 [15].

This intricate musical form unfolds across a wide spectrum of settings, ranging from lively fiestas (private parties) and intimate tablaos (Flamenco venues) to expansive concerts and elaborate productions in theaters. In each of these diverse contexts, the fundamental components of Flamenco music emerge: the cante (singing), the toque (instrument playing), and the baile (dance). Here, we focus on the song lyrics, and we demonstrate how they are intimately related to the different Flamenco genres.

Flamenco, while inherently individualistic, adheres to a highly structured framework. The tradition, characterized by a complex organization of styles and structures, allows for extensive improvisation within defined parameters. This implicit knowledge forms the foundation for spontaneous artistic expressions, wherein practitioners skillfully blend the fixed rhythmic, melodic, and harmonic structures of a specific style with a personalized set of expressive resources. This is naturally reflected in the lyrics, e.g., in formulaic expressions rooted in the traditional genre structure as we will see below.

In the Flamenco jargon genres or styles are called palos. Criteria adopted to define palos are rhythmic patterns, chord progressions, lyrics and their poetic structure, and geographical origin [4]. Due to its oral and traditional transmission and the inherent personal style of interpretation of the singing, genre classification of Flamenco music is often subject to personal interpretation and previous experience of the listener in Flamenco gatherings, leading even to academic discussions about the proper classification of some palos [16]. Here, following a quantitative approach, we investigate the Flamenco genre classification. Importantly, we find that Flamenco styles are characterized by unique lexical features as shown in their lyrics.

The foundational musical concepts and the evolutionary trajectory of Flamenco music remain largely uncharted. This dearth of documented information poses significant constraints on traditional musicological studies within the subject while serving as a compelling impetus for the development of computational tools dedicated to the description and analysis of Flamenco. While computational tools devoted to analyzing Flamenco art cover a wide range of specialties, such as biomechanical studies of baile (dance) [17], analysis of rhythmic similarity of cantes (singing) [18, 19], and creation of musical and informational databases [2, 4], to the best of our knowledge there is inexistent research addressing the computational analysis of Flamenco lyrics. This is the gap that we want to fill with our work.

Flamenco, as an oral music tradition, entails the transmission of songs and musical nuances across generations. Consequently, written scores are a rarity, given the intricate and complex melodic ornamentation inherent in vocal melodies. Even the records of renowned Flamenco festivals lack information about some features of the performances, including the lyrics [20]. The process of manual annotation, essential for capturing these nuances, is not only exceedingly time-consuming but also inevitably involves a subjective layer of interpretation.

In virtue of their aforementioned oral transmission which, while allowing for improvisation, firmly respects tradition, Flamenco lyrics are proven to describe the sociocultural context of their creators [21, 22]. Our interest lies in the systematic and large-scale analysis of Flamenco lyrics, to help us understand the different cultures and identities for which they constitute a historical vehicle of transmission. In this work, we quantitatively analyze the features of a corpus consisting of over 2000 manually-transcribed Flamenco lyrics with extensive metadata (title, album, singer, palo, etc.) available online [23].

To massively analyze large bunches of text we dispose of Natural Language Processing (NLP) tools. The newborn field of Lyrics Information Processing (LIP) [24] has proven to be successful in retrieving all kinds of information through the use of NLP for a computational analysis of lyrics outside Flamenco. Related works on automatic analysis of lyrics cover a wide range of applications such as the author classification of German songs [25], automatic detection of sexism in English songs [26], the age classification of Indonesian lyrics [27] or the identification of different writing styles in Taylor Swiftâ€™s songs [28], among others [29, 30, 31, 32]. However, to our knowledge, the computational analysis of Flamenco singersâ€™ production is limited to studies involving analysis of melody and related features [33, 34] rather than the content of their lyrics. We thus face an absence of LIP applications for Flamenco lyrics analysis.

Given the situation described above, our Research Questions (RQ) are:

1.

Can Flamenco palos be classified solely by means of their lexicon? If so, what is the characteristic lexicon of each palo?

2.

What relationships exist between the main Flamenco palos based on their lexicon?

To answer RQs 1 and 2 we analyze the corpus [23] and train a Multinomial Naive Bayes algorithm [35], a machine learning classification model widely used in text analysis.

We demonstrate that it is possible to differentiate between the main Flamenco genres and to properly classify them solely by their lyrics, and we determine the characteristic lexicon that allows us to do so (RQ1). We also compute lexical distances and propose a matrix of palo inter-relationships. These measures allow us to quantitatively prove some well-established facts about the origin and kinship of certain Flamenco genres (RQ2) and also propose open questions about some others.

II Results

In this section, we show the results obtained in our analysis of Flamenco lyrics to answer RQs 1 and 2. First, we explore the vocabulary richness and distribution of Flamenco genres through a computational analysis of our lyrics dataset. Later, we use a machine learning model to classify Flamenco songs based solely on their lexicon. Finally, we examine the relationships between the different palos based on their characteristic vocabulary.

II.1 Dataset

We analyze a corpus of Flamenco lyrics curated by Norman P. Kliman on his website [23]. This corpus agglutinates 3380 lyrics from 78 different styles or palos, featuring 276822 tokens (words) and 12981 types (unique words). The corpus is varied and diverse, exhibiting a structure characteristic of natural language corpora (see Appendix A).

As we can see in Fig. 1, not all the 78 different palos are equally represented, and only 8 of them count on more than 100 lyrics. Due to this, we decided to perform our analysis on the most represented genres, i.e., bulerÃ­as, soleÃ¡, seguiriyas, fandangos, tangos, tientos, malagueÃ±as, and alegrÃ­as. This set of the 8 most represented palos constitutes the reduced corpus to which, from now on, we will refer as the corpus for the sake of brevity.

Also, for the sake of clarity while reading this manuscript, we specify in Table 1 the acronyms with which we will refer to the aforementioned styles throughout the text and in the Figures. It is important to note that categorizing Flamenco songs into styles can be subjective, but for validation purposes, we rely on the classification provided by the album in which each song appears.

The corpus with the 8 most represented palos consists of 2216 song lyrics, 186798 tokens (words), and 10204 types (unique words).

After preprocessing the corpus, a necessary step previous to their computational analysis which involves deleting punctuation signs and accents and distinguishing between common and proper nouns (see Appendix A), we can extract information from the lexical structure of the lyrics. We now proceed to describe several findings in the process of corpus characterization.

Vocabulary size distribution.

One way to quantify the lexical richness of a text is to measure its vocabulary size |V|ğ‘‰|V|| italic_V |, i.e., the amount of types. In Fig. 2 we show the vocabulary size and the amount of tokens of the eight different styles or palos, computed as the vocabulary size of an aggregation of all the lyrics of each palo. BulerÃ­as account for the highest number of types used while malagueÃ±as restrict the range of use to a vocabulary almost 6 times lower in size. The overall ranking of token and type frequencies remains consistent across genres, with the exception of seguiriyas.

In the context of song-wise analysis, we may also observe in Fig. 3 that bulerÃ­as have the widest distribution of types used among songs, while malagueÃ±as, fandangos and seguiriyas are restricted to a similar number of types among songs. Cases like malagueÃ±as or alegrÃ­as resemble bimodal distributions, indicating that mainly two different vocabulary sizes characterize their lyrics. With these remarks, we can already infer that bulerÃ­as serve as the most polyvalent style, with the broadest vocabulary size distribution and the highest amount of types.

Standardized type-to-token ratio.

Another way of quantifying the lexical richness of a document is to compute its type-to-token ratio, Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…TTRitalic_T italic_T italic_R, i.e., the ratio between the amounts of types and tokens present in the document [37]:

where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the number of tokens (or document length). In this way, 1/Lâ‰¤Tâ¢Tâ¢Râ‰¤11ğ¿ğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…11/L\leq TTR\leq 11 / italic_L â‰¤ italic_T italic_T italic_R â‰¤ 1. The lower the Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…TTRitalic_T italic_T italic_R, the richer the document is in terms of the amount of times each type is used on average.

In our case, Eq. 1 is affected by the fact that some genres use more types than others, as we see in Fig. 2, while also having different amount of tokens and lyrics. For that reason, we use the standardized Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…TTRitalic_T italic_T italic_R, sâ¢Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…sTTRitalic_s italic_T italic_T italic_R, which is defined as the Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…TTRitalic_T italic_T italic_R averaged over several portions of the same document, with all the portions having the same number of tokens. For each palo we create a document compiling all the genreâ€™s lyrics. MalagueÃ±as is the genre with the least amount of tokens. Then, we take 50 portions of each genre with the length of the entire malagueÃ±as subcorpus and compute the mean sâ¢Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…sTTRitalic_s italic_T italic_T italic_R and its error except for malagueÃ±as, for which we take the entire genre a single time without error. We have checked that increasing the portion number above 50 does not significantly alter our results. We show the results in Fig. 4, where the solid line accounts for the sâ¢Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…sTTRitalic_s italic_T italic_T italic_R of the entire corpus, our null model for comparison.

The different values of sâ¢Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…sTTRitalic_s italic_T italic_T italic_R provide a partial answer to RQ1 by revealing that various Flamenco genres are distinguished by their unique vocabulary distributions and levels of richness. However, it is not clear that these measurements would allow for an unambiguous identification of a palo given some lyrics. For example, the vocabulary distribution is heavily influenced by the specific corpus used, and the reliability of sâ¢Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…sTTRitalic_s italic_T italic_T italic_R as a measure of lexical diversity independent of text length has been challenged [38]. Moreover, sâ¢Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…sTTRitalic_s italic_T italic_T italic_R values for some palos are close enough to be indistinguishable, as in the case of tangos and tientos, or bulerÃ­as and alegrÃ­as. To provide a comprehensive answer to RQ1, we need a more sophisticated approach. Thus, we will now examine the specific lexicon utilized by each palo using a machine learning algorithm which has proven to be useful in text analysis.

II.2 Palo classification

We employ a Multinomial Naive Bayes (MNB) model [35], a machine learning classification algorithm, to classify lyrics into distinct Flamenco genres or palos solely based on their lexical content. Initially, the corpus is partitioned into a training set comprising 85% of the data and a validation set containing the remaining 15%. The algorithm is then trained using the training set, leveraging the palo classifications provided in the dataset. Subsequently, the model performance is assessed using the validation set, wherein the genres assigned by the model are compared against the true genre labels associated with the lyrics. Further details about how this classification algorithm works are included in Appendix B.1.

Let us take a look at a single training of the algorithm. In Fig. 5 we show the confusion matrix of an arbitrary training. In this matrix, we can compare the percentage of lyrics of each genre that have been correctly or incorrectly classified. The true genre is shown in the vertical axis while the classification result is shown in the horizontal axis. Both seguiriyas and soleÃ¡ are correctly assigned in 90% of the times or more, and alegrÃ­as, bulerÃ­as, fandangos, in at least 75% of the cases.

Quite generally, different arrangements of lyrics for the training and validation sets yield different results. For this reason, we compute the accuracy of the model (the ratio of correct assignments) for 100 different trainings, obtaining the results shown in Fig. 6.

Despite the fact that genres like soleÃ¡ (85% mean accuracy), alegrÃ­as (88%) and seguiriyas (91%) are classified with outstanding accuracies, a few lyrics are incorrectly classified and therefore confused by the model. To examine these discrepancies, in Fig. 7 we plot the average confusion matrix of 100 different trainings and account only for the incorrect assignments.

Notably, we can identify several interesting confusions of the model. For example, the majority of confusions of bulerÃ­as (39%) are with soleÃ¡. The same confusion may be seen with 40% of tientos being confused with tangos, or with 53% of malagueÃ±as being confused with fandangos. These particular confusions are enlightening, as according to common wisdom, they are historically related genres. In the case of soleÃ¡ and bulerÃ­as, the latter is believed to have originated from the acceleration of the former ([14], p. 413). Another theory posits a hypothetical common origin for the two genres [39]. Similarly, tientos are known to be a slow variation of tangos, and malagueÃ±as are related to fandangos according to common wisdom. Remarkably, without any knowledge about the musical features or historical origin of the different genres, the algorithm can discern their relationships considering only their lexical content. We will later delve into these relationships.

It is evident how the aforementioned confusions affect the accuracy of the model, as in the cases of tangos (mean accuracy of 50%) and tientos (61%). However, Fig. 6 shows that soleÃ¡, alegrÃ­as and seguiriyas are classified with outstanding accuracies. Thus, we can assert that a classification of Flamenco lyrics based solely on their lexicon is quantitatively possible (RQ1), and that the inaccuracies are due to interesting palo relationships. Now, let us extract the lexical features that allow the model to classify the lyrics, i.e., the characteristic lexicon of each style.

II.3 Characteristic lexicon extraction

The MNB computes a metric called log-probability, logâ¡Pâ¢(w|C)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¤ğ¶\log P(w|C)roman_log italic_P ( italic_w | italic_C ), of each word wğ‘¤witalic_w for each palo Cğ¶Citalic_C (see Appendix B.1). The higher Pâ¢(w|C)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¤ğ¶P(w|C)italic_P ( italic_w | italic_C ) is, the more characteristic wğ‘¤witalic_w is for Cğ¶Citalic_C. We compute Pâ¢(w|C)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¤ğ¶P(w|C)italic_P ( italic_w | italic_C ) for several trainings of the algorithm and obtain results as shown in Fig. 8, where we can see the 15 most characteristic words, i.e., the 15 words with the largest value of logâ¡Pâ¢(w|C)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¤ğ¶\log P(w|C)roman_log italic_P ( italic_w | italic_C ), for two example styles, C=Ağ¶AC=\mathrm{A}italic_C = roman_A (alegrÃ­as) [Fig. 8a)] and C=Seğ¶SeC=\mathrm{Se}italic_C = roman_Se (seguiriyas) [Fig. 8c)].

While alegrÃ­as feature as most characteristic words references to places such as Cadiz, Muralla Real â€™Royal Wallâ€™ or mar â€™seaâ€™ (all related to Cadiz and its harbors), and other less specific words such as llevar â€™to take/bringâ€™, voy â€™I goâ€™, conmigo â€™with meâ€™, seguiriyas are biased towards abstract and profound concepts such as Dios â€™Godâ€™, alma â€™soulâ€™, libertad â€™freedomâ€™ and desgracia â€™misfortuneâ€™. We will later interpret the characteristic words in Sec. III, and see how these words clearly differentiate between genres.

The vocabularies of different Flamenco palos are generally large, consisting of thousands of unique words. In addition, the log-probability distribution for a given Flamenco genre, as seen in Fig. 9 for C=Ağ¶AC=\mathrm{A}italic_C = roman_A (alegrÃ­as), is smooth and does not allow to retrieve a set of characteristic words. To perform an analysis of the main lexical fields, it is necessary to choose a threshold amount of words, ranked based on their log-probability. However, to make this threshold non-arbitrary, we define a set of essential words for each genre. For a word to be considered essential in a genre, it must fulfill stringent requirements in addition to being among the most characteristic words of the genre. Basically, an essential word maintains its high relevance for a given genre throughout all trainings. Hence, we use the first word with a minimum relevance in at least one training as a threshold. These requirements are explained in detail in Appendix B.2.

The number of essential words within each palo serves for distinguishing among various Flamenco genres. Table 2 presents the count of essential words per palo, denoted as Nesubscriptğ‘ğ‘’N_{e}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Notably, while malagueÃ±as have 16 essential words, soleÃ¡â€™s essential lexicon is significantly larger, averaging 186 words, i.e., nearly 12 times more. Despite this, as illustrated in Fig. 2, malagueÃ±as exhibit a far smaller vocabulary compared to soleÃ¡. To account for the impact of vocabulary size on the essential lexicon, we normalize Nesubscriptğ‘ğ‘’N_{e}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by the vocabulary size, |V|ğ‘‰|V|| italic_V |, as depicted in Fig. 10. When adjusted for vocabulary size, seguiriyas boasts the largest essential lexicon, while soleÃ¡â€™s normalized essential lexicon (5.5%) is only four times greater than that of malagueÃ±as (1.5%). The complete lists of these words for all Flamenco genres in descending order of log-probability are included in Appendix C. We emphasize that the relevance of these words is automatically detected and is therefore free of subjective biases. This is a clear advantage of our application of computational classification methods.

Now that we have demonstrated that each genre exhibits its own peculiarity in the lexical distribution and variation of its lyrics, the natural question is RQ2, namely, what relationships exist between the main Flamenco palos based on their lexicon?

II.4 Relationship between palos

To address RQ2, we quantify the lexical diversity across different palos. Hence, we utilize the cosine distance measure of lexical distance between documents (refer to Appendix B.3 for further details and definition), which ranges between 0, indicating a close resemblance between documents, and 1, indicating a significant difference between documents. Our approach involves compiling a single document for each genre by concatenating all its lyrics. Subsequently, we compute the distance between these aggregations.

In Fig. 11, we present the pairwise distance matrix between palos, where we find intriguing patterns. For instance, alegrÃ­as appear to be the most distant style, exhibiting the highest distance from all other styles. In contrast, tientos and tangos exhibit remarkable proximity with a distance of 0.26, while bulerÃ­as and soleÃ¡ also demonstrate close associations, with an also small distance of 0.28. The hierarchical clustering revealed by the dendrogram positioned atop the matrix offers insights into these observations. Specifically, it elucidates the amalgamation of tientos and tangos or bulerÃ­as and soleÃ¡ into two clusters, which further incorporate fandangos, and so forth.

The distances between Flamenco styles are therefore helpful in addressing RQ2. To provide a more concrete analysis, we adopt a network representation. In Fig. 12, we present a fully-connected network illustrating the distances between styles, enabling a straightforward visual assessment of their relationships. Each node represents a style, and the edges vary in thickness and color depending on the cosine distance values. The network structure provides insights into the relationships among different palos in several ways. As observed in the dendrogram, alegrÃ­as emerges as the most lexically distinct palo. The remaining palos form a more tightly interconnected network, with bulerÃ­as, soleÃ¡, and tangos prominently contributing to its connectivity. Additionally, the size of the nodes in the network graph corresponds to their closeness centrality, a measure in network analysis that quantifies how close a node is to all other nodes in the network ([40], p. 146), suggesting their significance in facilitating connections between different musical forms. This network representation proves advantageous as it facilitates the extraction of spanning trees ([40], p. 27), which are sub-networks that connect all genres such that each genre is linked directly or indirectly to every other genre, without creating any cycles, thereby maintaining the network connectivity. By selecting the minimum spanning tree (MST), which minimizes the sum of distances between palos, we obtain the representation depicted in Fig. 13, i.e., the MST of Flamenco palos. This approach enables a structured exploration of the relationships between palos, shedding light on their hierarchical organization within the Flamenco genre.

III Discussion

By answering RQs 1 and 2 we have proven that Flamenco genres can be distinguished by means of their vocabulary, and also that the study of their lexical variation can establish relationships between different palos. We now delve into the meaning of the quantitative results obtained computationally and explore their implications.

At first glance, regarding the sâ¢Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…sTTRitalic_s italic_T italic_T italic_R analysis, in Fig. 4 we can see that sâ¢Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…sTTRitalic_s italic_T italic_T italic_R is genre-distinctive. Indeed, returning to the results of the vocabulary size distribution in Fig. 3, if we focus on the sâ¢Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…sTTRitalic_s italic_T italic_T italic_R values, we can see how bulerÃ­as make lower use of their types than malagueÃ±as do, even though the vocabulary of the latter is significantly lower than the vocabulary of the former. This indicates that while bulerÃ­as are rather varied and move within a wide range of topics, this genre makes relatively less use of their topics than malagueÃ±as do. Values above the null modelâ€™s sâ¢Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…sTTRitalic_s italic_T italic_T italic_R indicate a more developed use of a specific set of types, while values below indicate either a wider use of types or a less developed use of the available types.

However, sâ¢Tâ¢Tâ¢Rğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘‡ğ‘…sTTRitalic_s italic_T italic_T italic_R values do not provide insights into the specific lexical usage across different Flamenco styles. To address this, we employ the MNB model to identify a set of essential words for each genre. As illustrated in Fig. 10, the quantity of essential words already varies noticeably across genres. In terms of the number of essential words, malagueÃ±as and bulerÃ­as have the fewest, while seguiriyas and soleÃ¡ stand out. Establishing an amount of essential words for each Flamenco style enables us to analyze the topics reflected in each genreâ€™s set of essential words.

Flamenco encompasses a variety of genres, each with its own unique origins, tones, and topics. For instance, alegrÃ­as are typical from CÃ¡diz and are typically fast-paced and celebratory, while seguiriyas tend to be slower, more intimate, and melancholic, highly related to the gipsy peopleâ€™s sorrows and sufferings. These distinctions in the essence of various genres are reflected in the variation of their lexicon, as shown in Fig. 8.

Before describing the particular features of the essential lexicon of each style, we first identify four primary groups of relevant words (lexical fields) that largely determine the palo variation.

First, we find words related to geographical places and day-to-day life. As previously mentioned, Flamenco lyrics are transmitted orally and encompass a tradition of livings and history. Thus it is common to find references to these topics. Thus, while alegrÃ­as feature lexicon related to CÃ¡diz, Navarre and titirimundis â€™puppets showâ€™, malagueÃ±as refer to the Corte â€™Court, Capitalâ€™ (Madrid), tangos talk about wars and bulerÃ­as feature references to Seville and proper names like Amparo, Dolores or MarÃ­a.

Secondly, we also find references to gipsies and their families and culture, due to the intense influence of this ethnic group in Flamenco art throughout its history. We obtain specific words like gitano/a â€™gipsyâ€™, and common words like madre â€™motherâ€™, padre â€™fatherâ€™, or primo/a â€™cousinâ€™, usually in a gipsy context. Interestingly, seguiriyas and soleÃ¡ genres even feature CalÃ³ vocabulary [21] as characteristic words. The use of CalÃ³, a dialect of Romani language spoken by the gipsies of Spain ([41], p. 125), further connects these genres to the gipsy people.

We find evidence for the belief that Flamenco accompanied gipsies and Andalusian people in times of sorrow and high suffering [22] in lexicon related to deep pain, such as dolor â€™painâ€™, desgracia â€™misfortuneâ€™, llorar â€™to cryâ€™, pena â€™sorrowâ€™, traiciÃ³n â€™betrayalâ€™, muerta â€™dead (singular feminine)â€™. This semantic field constitutes a third group, along with lexicon related to joy and love. Flamenco is also used to accompany fiestas and celebrations, such as the famous gipsy weddings, and thus we may find highly characteristic words such as adoro â€™I adoreâ€™, quiero â€™I want/loveâ€™, and amor â€™loveâ€™.

Finally, we find a fourth group involving abstract concepts such as perdÃ³n â€™forgivenessâ€™, alma â€™soulâ€™ or libertad â€™freedomâ€™ in palos like soleÃ¡, and religious references to God, Christ and to some saints such as Santiago â€™Saint Jamesâ€™, Santa Ana â€™Saint Anneâ€™, or the Virgin Mary.

It is relevant to note that the aforementioned lexicon and others participate in formulaic structures or cliches, i.e., fixed expressions that are frequently utilized. Flamenco, being a highly traditional and orally-transmitted art, preserves the structure and lexicon of each styleâ€™s lyrics, while still allowing for innovation. These fixed expressions constitute coherent stanzas that are typically not semantically connected to the rest of the lyrics but are highly characteristic of a given style and are transmitted from one generation of singers to another. A very recognizable example of a formulaic structure in alegrÃ­as is

a CÃ¡diz no le llaman CÃ¡diz

que le llaman relicario

porque tienen por patrona

a la Virgen del Rosario

â€™Cadiz is not called Cadiz

but itâ€™s called reliquary

because they have as patron saint

the Virgin of the Rosaryâ€™,

in which the words relicario â€™reliquaryâ€™ or patrona â€™patron saintâ€™ acquire relevance without being semantically connected to the topics of the rest of the lyrics.

Therefore, we face lyrics with a very rich lexical variation. Not only do Flamenco styles feature cultural variation, but also geographical, ethnic, dialectal, and sentimental variation. We now proceed to describe the overall features of the essential words of each Flamenco style. Here, we highlight a selection of essential words from each genre, specifically those having a greater or more intriguing semantic charge. In Appendix C we include the complete list of essential words for each palo.

Among the essential words of alegrÃ­as genre, we find terms related to geography such as Muralla Real â€™Royal Wallâ€™, Navarra â€™Navarreâ€™, CÃ¡diz â€™Cadizâ€™, San Fernando â€™Saint Ferdinandâ€™, mar â€™seaâ€™, barrio â€™neighborhoodâ€™, and Zaragoza, the capital of Aragon. This is consistent with the purported origin of alegrÃ­as stemming from the dynamization of Aragonese jota music during the French occupation, with a clear Aragonese influence ([14] p. 325-236).

BulerÃ­as are one of the most gipsy and festive palos. With origins in festivity and mockery [42], bulerÃ­as often feature improvisations at the end of musical performances attended by the gipsy community or in gipsy neighborhoods of Spanish cities. In bulerÃ­as we find multiple stanzas regarding the virtues of being a gipsy, featuring anecdotes about beauty, kindness, and recurring themes of love, including essential words such as gitano/a â€™gypsy (sing.)â€™, primo/a â€™cousin (sing.)â€™, quiero â€™I want/loveâ€™, querer â€™to loveâ€™, contigo â€™with youâ€™, bonita â€™beautiful (fem. sing.)â€™. Another interesting set of essential words is that of female names, such as MarÃ­a, Dolores, or Amparo. These are usually Spanish polysemes â€“ MarÃ­a may refer to the Virgin Mary, amparo â€™shelterâ€™, dolores â€™painsâ€™. The pains, the bad, and the sorrows are typical of bulerÃ­as, in conjunction with Seville, family, religion, and love.

In malagueÃ±as and fandangos genres we find references to deep sorrows and religion (llorar â€™to cryâ€™, llorando â€™cryingâ€™, pena â€™pain, sorrowâ€™, traiciÃ³n â€™betrayalâ€™, muere â€™he/she diesâ€™, morir â€™to dieâ€™; muerte â€™deathâ€™ is the most characteristic word of malagueÃ±as), but also intensely to the love to women (in fandangos, mujer â€™womanâ€™ is the most essential word, followed by querÃ­a â€™I wanted/I lovedâ€™ and querer â€™to want/loveâ€™), as fandangos are usually devoted to sending love messages or love declarations. An interesting lexical feature of fandangos is the essential phraseme cinco sentidos â€™five sensesâ€™, which is directly related to love dependence. As the lover constitutes the five senses of the singer, when the lover is lost, the singer is found suffering and losing the five senses. Also among the essential words of malagueÃ±as we find lexical references to desperation and profound emotions, such as amaba â€™I lovedâ€™ and delirio â€™deliriumâ€™. Both malagueÃ±as and fandangos are referred to as the cantes â€™songsâ€™ of MÃ¡laga, so it is not surprising that they cover similar lexical fields.

Seguiriyas are believed to be, along with soleÃ¡, the gipsiest and purest Flamenco styles. Indeed, both styles include characteristic references to CalÃ³ lexicon, such as duquelas â€™fatigues, painsâ€™, camelar â€™to desire, consent, enamorâ€™, Undebel â€™Godâ€™, and terelar â€™to have, possessâ€™. Seguiriyas and soleÃ¡ also primarily refer to situations of distress and suffering. For this reason, we can find references to sad, deep concepts such as Dios â€™Godâ€™, culpa â€™guiltâ€™, noche â€™nightâ€™, ciencia â€™scienceâ€™, infierno â€™hellâ€™, muerte â€™deathâ€™, alma â€™soulâ€™, tierra â€™earthâ€™, madre â€™motherâ€™, or pena â€™pain, sorrowâ€™. Interestingly, seguiriyas feature specific references to clavo â€™cloveâ€™, clavito â€™little cloveâ€™, canela â€™cinnamonâ€™, huele â€™smellsâ€™, and hueles â€™you smellâ€™, all of them related to a formulaic expression related to a bath ritual believed in the Romani culture to have beneficial effects in life.

In tangos, there are characteristic mentions of geographical locations such as the town of Utrera or the Seville neighborhood of Triana, including its famous puente â€™bridgeâ€™. Dios â€™Godâ€™ is also present, surrounded by other religious references such as Virgen â€™Virginâ€™ or Humildad â€™Humilityâ€™ in reference to the Christ of Humility. Additionally, around guerra â€™warâ€™ we find allusions to historical conflicts, specifically the Cuban and French wars, are viewed through a Spanish historical lens.

Overall, tangos engage deeply with emotions, covering a spectrum from sorrow (pena â€™painâ€™, fatigas â€™fatigues, painsâ€™), to love, happiness and joy (querer â€™to want/loveâ€™, bonita â€™beautiful (fem. sing.)â€™, alegrÃ­a â€™joyâ€™).

Finally, tientos share much of their semantic content with tangos, encompassing human emotions and religious themes. This is observed in the use of lexicon such as querer â€™to want/loveâ€™, pena â€™pain, sorrowâ€™, Dios â€™Godâ€™, Virgen â€™Virginâ€™, and guerra â€™warâ€™. Nonetheless, references to geographical places are less frequent. Predominantly, the essential vocabulary of tientos pertains to formulaic expressions, such as serrana â€™mountain womanâ€™, vente â€™you comeâ€™, conmigo â€™with meâ€™, darÃ© â€™I will giveâ€™ in

Vente conmigo serrana

te darÃ© caÃ±a dulce

que te traigo de La Habana.

â€™Come with me, mountain girl

Iâ€™ll give you sweet sugar cane

that I bring from Havana.â€™

Vocabulary not only characterizes each Flamenco genre but also establishes relationships among the styles. In Fig. 13 we observe four distinct branches converging at bulerÃ­as, serving as a unifying node. These branches encompass a gipsy branch involving seguiriyas and soleÃ¡, a branch (presumably) originating from MÃ¡laga comprising malagueÃ±as and fandangos, and the branch of tangos, encompassing tangos and tientos. Importantly, the MST representation effectively encapsulates known historical relationships among palos. For instance, our result aligns with established historical accounts such as the derivation of tientos from a deceleration of tangos ([14], p. 338), and sheds light on lesser-known connections, such as the relationship between malagueÃ±as and fandangos. While the origin of the latter is discussed by various theories ([14], p. 420), our finding supports the understanding of current fandangos as traditional songs originating from MÃ¡laga, thereby linking them to malagueÃ±as [43].

In the middle of the four branches, bulerÃ­as act as a nexus, also allowing alegrÃ­as to connect to the rest of the palos. This may be related to the high vocabulary richness of bulerÃ­as lyrics and would be interesting to elaborate on in further research. Due to the natural habitat of bulerÃ­as (entertainment in gipsy meetings, festive ending of Flamenco fiestas) this genre could be drawn towards using a wider and richer vocabulary, leading to act as a nexus to the rest of the palos.

IV Conclusions

To sum up, we have quantitatively analyzed the lexical variations in Flamenco lyrics using computational methods for text analysis and machine learning for classification. Our work constitutes a proof of concept to quantify lexical features of Flamenco lyrics and subsequently relate them to history and culture.

First, we have addressed RQ1, can Flamenco palos be classified solely by means of their lexicon? If so, what is the characteristic lexicon of each palo? Our findings demonstrate that, with varying degrees of accuracy, it is indeed possible to automatically classify Flamenco songs into their respective palos based solely on their lexicon. This discovery holds significant relevance for Flamenco palo classification, which have thus far relied largely on subjective judgment.

The fact that palo classification is possible based only on the content of their lyrics shows that lyrics of different palos encode different information, due to their different origins, history, and habitats. By performing a discussion and interpretation of the essential lexicon of each palo, we have identified insightful differences between Flamenco styles. While alegrÃ­as are mainly festive and referent to CÃ¡diz, seguiriyas cover deep concerns and embody gipsy terms, while bulerÃ­as covers a wide range of topics and vocabulary maybe due to its use as an instrument of anmmenization and celebration.

In virtue of this differentiative characteristic lexicon, we have answered RQ2, what relationships exist between the main Flamenco palos based on their lexicon?, computing a lexical distance between palos. With this metric we have been able to identify four different branches of Flamenco constituted mainly by gipsy styles, cantes (singings) from MÃ¡laga, tangos, and alegrÃ­as, with a common nexus in bulerÃ­as. Our Minimum Spanning Tree representation allows us to quantitatively support historical theories on the relationship of malagueÃ±as and fandangos or between tientos and tangos.

Finally, our study is not without its limitations. Unlike mainstream genres like reggaeton, pop, or rock, Flamencoâ€™s limited availability of large lyric databases complicates analysis, further compounded by its rich collection of styles. While our study benefited from a reasonably curated corpus, the dataset still lacked representation of numerous palos. Moreover, among those genres that were sufficiently represented, there were notable disparities in representation: some were significantly more represented than others, underscoring the corpus-dependency of our analysis and conclusions. Future research should aim to address these limitations by expanding the scope of data collection efforts, thereby enhancing the robustness and generalizability of findings. Moreover, a change in the preprocessing stage, stop words, or other parameters of our analysis may yield different results, but we believe that the main conclusions of the current study will remain valid. Also, incorporating advanced text processing techniques such as lemmatization or stemming could refine our analysis [44] and yield deeper insights into the lexical nuances of Flamenco lyrics. As Flamenco continues to evolve, marked by contemporary references like Moneoâ€™s mention of the coronavirus in recent performances [45], ongoing research efforts must adapt to capture and interpret these dynamic shifts in the genreâ€™s lexical content. To sum up, embracing quantitative methods and interdisciplinary applications have allowed us to uncover Flamencoâ€™s linguistic and cultural legacy, thereby deepening our appreciation for this iconic musical tradition.

Appendix B Additional methods

During our analysis of Flamenco lyrics, we have employed various computational tools. This section elaborates on the methodologies utilized, encompassing machine learning model implementation, definition and identification of essential words, and computation of lexical distances between documents.

B.1 Multinomial Naive Bayes

Our goal is to extract the characteristic lexicon of each of the 8 Flamenco palos that we have in our corpus. For that, we train a machine learning model called Multinomial Naive Bayes (MNB) classifier with Lidstone smoothing [35, 47]. In the following section we include an explanation of the MNB algorithm, only for completeness, as this is a standard approach.

MNB.

First, to feed the MNB, we represent the documents with a term-frequency inverse-document-frequency (TF-IDF) matrix instead of a word-count matrix. We do this because the TF-IDF metric accounts not only for the frequency of use of a given word in the corpus but also for how scarcely (or predominantly) the word is distributed among documents. We now proceed to describe how to assess the actual performance of the model when classifying new documents.

Assessment of the classification performance.

We divide our corpus in two sets of documents, the training and the validation sets. The training set is used by the model to learn the characteristic lexicon of each class, i.e., to compute Eq. 3. This is the training process. Once the model is trained, its performance is assessed by computing Eq. 4 for each document of the validation set and comparing these scores with the actual class to which the documents pertain. Let us consider two styles P1 and P2. If the model classifies as P1 certain lyrics pertaining to P1 style, this is a correct assignment. On the contrary, should the actual style of the lyrics be P2, this will be a confusion of the model. With this information we build a confusion matrix as the one in Fig 5.

The metric used to perform the assessment is called accuracy, and refers to the ratio of correct assignments, i.e., the number of correct classifications divided by the total amount of classifications.

There are several degrees of freedom that affect the accuracy of the model. One of them is the size and composition of the training and validation sets. We configure the size of the training and validation sets to be 85% and 15% of the whole corpus, respectively, forcing the distribution of styles in each set to be equal and representative of that of the whole corpus. The model then learns with 85% of the lyrics, and we assess its performance on the remaining 15%. The impact of the training and validation set compositions on accuracy is obscured by averaging relevant measures such as the accuracy itself across multiple training sessions with varying training and validation set compositions.

Another parameter that might affect the accuracy is Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± (see Eq. 3). We now proceed to show how we optimize the training process using Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±.

Training optimization.

Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± avoids the zero-frequency problem [35]. To look for the optimal value of Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, we perform several trainings and validations of the model for different values of Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± given a chosen training size of 85% of the corpus which respects the global distribution of lyrics within styles (see Fig. 1). We look for maximum accuracy.

For 200 different trainings, we iterate Î±âˆˆ[0,1]ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1]italic_Î± âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ], in steps of 0.0050.0050.0050.005. On average, the maximum global accuracy, i.e., the maximum ratio of correct assignments in the entire training set, is achieved for Î±=0.11ğ›¼0.11\alpha=0.11italic_Î± = 0.11, as shown in Fig. 16.

With these values of Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± and training size, the model behaves as shown in the confusion matrix of Fig. 5 and in the accuracy ranking of Fig. 6. The accuracies are reasonably good for most of the styles. A few styles do not perform as well, due to lexical similarities which are discussed in Section II.

B.2 Essential words

In virtue of Pâ¢(w|C)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¤ğ¶P(w|C)italic_P ( italic_w | italic_C ), defined in Eq. 4, each style has a ranking of words, as there are words which have a larger conditional probability of pertaining to a given style than others.

For each random set of training lyrics we will obtain a different set of Pâ¢(w|C)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¤ğ¶P(w|C)italic_P ( italic_w | italic_C ) for a given style Cğ¶Citalic_C. If we compute the mean for a set of trainings we obtain a decreasing curve as a function of the rank of wğ‘¤witalic_w. In Fig. 9 we show as an example the Pâ¢(w|C)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¤ğ¶P(w|C)italic_P ( italic_w | italic_C ) distribution for alegrÃ­as.

As we rank words for each style based on the mean value of the different Pâ¢(w|C)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¤ğ¶P(w|C)italic_P ( italic_w | italic_C ) computed over multiple training iterations, we observe that, for each iteration, the minimum probability is obtained for several words. This occurrence arises because these words fail to appear in a sufficient number of lyrics to be consistently present across all random sets of training data. To address this issue and identify a set of characteristic words for each style, we rank words based on their average Pâ¢(w|C)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¤ğ¶P(w|C)italic_P ( italic_w | italic_C ) and look for the first word that had the minimum Pâ¢(w|C)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¤ğ¶P(w|C)italic_P ( italic_w | italic_C ) in at least one realization (see red dot in Fig. 9). The rank of that word defines a threshold, and we term all words ranked above the threshold as essential.The quantity of essential words per style is depicted in Figure 10. There, it is clear that different styles have significantly different amounts of essential words. The complete list of essential words for each style is provided in Appendix C.

B.3 Distance and clustering

To compute the similarity between different styles we use cosine distance. This is a measure used to quantify the similarity between two document vectors in a multidimensional space. In our case, our vectors are the normalized rows of the TF-IDF matrix, as detailed in Section B.

If we consider two document vectors ğ“ğŸsubscriptğ“1\mathbf{T_{1}}bold_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ“ğŸsubscriptğ“2\mathbf{T_{2}}bold_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the cosine distance (CD) between these vectors is calculated using the cosine of the angle between them in their multidimensional space, as

CDâ¢(ğ“ğŸ,ğ“ğŸ)=1âˆ’ğ“ğŸâ‹…ğ“ğŸ,CDsubscriptğ“1subscriptğ“21â‹…subscriptğ“1subscriptğ“2\text{CD}(\mathbf{T_{1}},\mathbf{T_{2}})=1-\mathbf{T_{1}}\cdot\mathbf{T_{2}},CD ( bold_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1 - bold_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (5)

where ğ“ğŸâ‹…ğ“ğŸâ‹…subscriptğ“1subscriptğ“2\mathbf{T_{1}}\cdot\mathbf{T_{2}}bold_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the dot product between vectors ğ“ğŸsubscriptğ“1\mathbf{T_{1}}bold_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ“ğŸsubscriptğ“2\mathbf{T_{2}}bold_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

CD ranges between 0 and 1. A value of 0 indicates that the two vectors are identical (perfect similarity), while a value of 1 implies that the vectors are orthogonal (completely dissimilar).

In the context of analyzing Flamenco lyrics, CD can be used to compare the lexical similarity between different styles. By representing each style compilation, i.e., an aggregation of all the lyrics of a given style, as a document vector of TF-IDF values, we can calculate the cosine distance between pairs of styles to determine their similarity.

Once a distance metric between styles has been established, we proceed with hierarchical clustering [48] to organize them into clusters. Given the presence of 8 styles, we initialize the process with the 8 aggregations. The hierarchical clustering algorithm begins by assigning the first cluster to the two closest documents. Subsequently, this formed cluster is treated as a single document, and the distance matrix is updated accordingly. This iterative process continues until only one cluster remains. The dendrogram positioned atop the distance matrix in Fig. 11 visually depicts this hierarchical clustering process.
